Legal_Issue: Whether the RAD erred in applying the reasonableness standard to the RPD's findings of fact and mixed fact and law
Application_Facts: Ms. Yani Meilina appealed the RAD's dismissal of her refugee claim, arguing the wrong standard of review was applied
Decision_Outcome: The application for judicial review is granted, and the case is remitted to a different RAD member for re-determination
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the RAD's decision
Court_Ruling: The RAD's decision was set aside, and the matter was sent back for reconsideration under the appropriate standard
Defendant_Behavior: RAD applied the reasonableness standard to RPD's findings
Grounds_for_Claim: Allegation that an incorrect standard of review was applied by the RAD
Assessment_Factor: Significance of the legal issue to the administrative law system
Procedural_Issue: Standard of review in administrative decision-making
Review_Standard: Reasonableness standard was applied; court determined correctness standard should have been used
Relief_Sought: Remittal of the case for re-determination by a different RAD member
Governing_Rule: The correctness standard applies to questions of central importance to the legal system; otherwise, reasonableness applies unless involving constitutional or jurisdictional issues
Outcome: RAD decision set aside; case remitted
Harm_Assessment: Potential denial of fair refugee status determination due to incorrect legal standard
Cause_Description: Ms. Yani Meilina appealed the RAD's dismissal of her refugee claim, arguing the wrong standard of review was applied
Jurisdictional_Issue: Question of whether deference is owed to RPD findings on matters of significant legal importance
Decision_Rationale: The issue is significant enough to warrant the correctness standard rather than reasonableness
Decision_Making_Body: Refugee Protection Division (RPD), Refugee Appeal Division (RAD)
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard initially applied by RAD; court held correctness standard should apply
